hey dude, in year 12 currently, studying architecture at USYD from next year :) Anyhow, I would advise that you use sketchup make/pro; the other programs that I know of for building are quite complex (eg Revit, Autocad). Sketchup on the other hand is much simpler, and all though it may LOOK shit when you create a building on the program you can use (free) programs like Visualiser to render the building. As for model materials, I personally feel you should use materials that best reflect the textures and the "weight" of the building, so give that some thought. If you can make more than one model, I don't see why you couldn't make one model for the Hanok and then do a cross section to show what's inside. I did something similar for my design portfolio project but unfortunately they didn't let us use models. Good luck with your project and with year 12!! Hope these suggestions help :)

Hello, this sounds like my previous relationship! I went through something very similar actually: after my boyfriend cheated on me, I immediately suspected and accused him multiple times, to which he denied the validity of my thoughts and frequently intimated I was essentially an asshole for suggesting such a thing in the first place. First thing: When you accuse someone of something you know they have done and they try to deny the validity of your thoughts by implying you're crazy, touched in the head and so on, that is called gaslighting. And it is considered a form of abuse. Like you, I also took my partner back. Bad move. He treated me badly, albeit in subtler ways the second time around, again similar to your partner. Anyhow, there is plenty you can take from this. Firstly, you were abused, make no mistake, and I recommend that you find an outlet for expressing your emotions, be that sport, talking to friends/family, a hobby, or therapy. For me, the pain is still fresh from the relationship but if you actively work everyday to make yourself feel better, you WILL make progress. Don't let a destructive person ruin your relationship AND your mental health, too. Secondly, the answer to your question is no. Does it happen a lot? Yes. The honest truth is, dating for young people such as you and I is incredibly fickle. People are assholes at our age, and unfortunately cheating behaviour as a young adult tends to persist as one gets older, too. But, there is hope. Next time you find someone who takes your fancy, don't rush into things. Really take your time to get to know them (and them you), and make sure you know what you're getting into. Even then, don't be too trusting. Don't automatically assume the best of someone, especially in the honeymoon phase. And more importantly, don't give people a second chance. Regardless of what people say, cheating is never excusable, and anyone who does it once while do it again. Stay wary.

Thank you for the advice! You #8217;re very much right about the fact that I #8217;m emotionally maturing; I have definitely learnt a lot about myself and the world since coming out last year. That being said, this issue is not just a personal one, it #8217;s also a deep sorrow for the poisonous and toxic culture that we have allowed to perpetuate in the gay community. We are a people who have been marginalised for such a long time, and to see how the gay community puts people into boxes and shamed them is devastating; people have died for being homosexual and people have died to advance our cause. It is atrocious that we throw that away by being toxic and nasty to each other. I see this particularly from my viewpoint as a brown person who is gay in a white society. The honest truth is, I like the way I look, but the way brown men look just tends to be different to the way white men look, so I was never even in the running for meeting society #8217;s expectations for how I should look (because it #8217;s a white persons game). What I don #8217;t appreciate is how this ties in to being seen as lesser in the gay world, it #8217;s proof that racism is still very much alive when someone like me, with my darkish-olive complexion, short stature and relatively slim body is automatically placed into a lesser category. These are things people need to be made aware; gay people already have a much higher suicide rate when compared to Hetero population, so let #8217;s not put up more divisions to eliminate any possibility of a welcoming and inclusive community. Anyway, enough rambling from me. Thank you very much for your response, I really appreciate the time you put into it. Bless.

I live in Australia and it #8217;s hard to imagine how badly residents in America are treated compared to us. In Australia, in your intern year you generally get paid $65000 a year (roughly), which is just over 50k USD and usually work between 48-55 hours a week. Only a very small percentage of interns regularly work more than 60 hours a week. I can #8217;t believe how little US residents are paid to work, what, 80-90 hours a week on average? It #8217;s awful and it #8217;s mistreatment of a valuable workforce.

The question is whether or not it #8217;s good for the patients to have people put under extreme pressure with extreme hours to earn relatively little, particularly with new doctors. There #8217;s been a lot of research done in Australia showing how doctors ability to treat is hindered by extreme working hours.

I don #8217;t understand the American health care system. For those of you who are in North America, I don #8217;t think you guys realise how different the healthcare field is there to much of the outside world. The first thing I notice is there are a whole slew of jobs in the US that I have never heard of, and in each #8220;traditional #8221; occupation there seems to be a lot of #8220;stratification #8221; of professionals (an example being having Paramedics, but then EMTs with a smaller scope of practice and less training). I find it odd, to perfectly honest. I don #8217;t think prescribing independently and practising independently and doing god knows what else independently should be a valid option for most professions. After all, all healthcare degrees are hard, but I think we can all be honest and admit the MD is the hardest; realistically, I don #8217;t think every profession should have some sort of #8220;prescribing #8221; option or some #8220;ability to treat independently #8221; option. Doctors go to medical school for that reason, and I feel that allowing each profession to encroach on the physicians scope of practice will only encourage division amongst health care practitioners. Furthermore, I thought in the 21st century we were supposed to be moving into a healthcare model that advocates #8220;a collaborative health care team centred on the patient #8221;? My take is that means that there is greater recognition in the 21st century of the important roles each type of health care practitioner plays in patient management, and implies that each practitioner has something unique to offer. I don #8217;t see that with advocating for an increased scope of practice in every profession. With the exception of pharmacist prescribing, I feel that the current trend I see in the US is all the professions moving towards having a doctor-like scope of practice. Why cant we just acknowledge that certain professionals have a different scope of practice? I feel that the constant expansion of scope of practice completely forgoes the fact that each professional has something unique and distinct to offer in practice, such as pharmacists being medication management and nurses being ongoing care. Here is my message from a country with a totally different system: everyone in healthcare has something valuable and distinct to contribute to patient management. You don #8217;t need to become a doctor or a prescriber to be worthwhile to the wider healthcare system.

It's one of those things that people seem to be ok with on the surface but they really aren't. I live in Australia which is one of the worlds most developed countries yet in my state me and my (gay) partner couldn't adopt a child unless a social worker went back to the parents who gave the child up for adoption and got their permission. This only applies to gay people, and not any other minority. While this may be the case in San Francisco, you notice that there is not a great amount of emphasis placed on setting in the show; it could be anywhere, especially to an outsider from America. As a result, you can imagine that the show is written to resonate with the widest audience as possible, and not just those who have grown up in liberal San Francisco. Statistically, San Francisco would represent the extreme end of the bell curve for liberal values and LGBT rights in the world; the vast majority of people who watch the show will not be from there and as a result, they are more likely to have had experiences that may see synchrony with Courtney's feelings. I don't think Courtney is a bad person. She has done horrible things, yes. But ultimately, she is a young woman who belongs to several minorities who just wants to fit in and blend. Not an uncommon theme amongst teenagers and a theme that is certainly very prevalent in 13 Reasons Why. When I came out, I had so much extra pressure put on me due to the fact I already had a gay brother. I had to worry about how people would perceive us and I felt constantly anxious about appearing like a dysfunctional family. So I invested everything into being as perfect as I could be: I was like Courtney in the sense that I was popular, academically smart and participated in lots of activities. Whether those pressures are real or not is irrelevant, because you don't want to be the one that causes pain to the rest of your family, so you preempt it and try to protect yourself. I don't think Courtney's experience should be underestimated, I feel that she has more than enough to deal with.

It's also a thing for other ethnicities. I appear to most people as Indian-looking but because I have relatively light (compared to an Indian), olive skin, there is constant debate about "what I am". White people don't consider me white. Non-white people don't consider me white. But all hell breaks loose if I call myself brown. It's a mystery to me.

I hardly agree. It's not "because they are women", it's because medical literature and clinical practice has not researched enough into the possibilities of behavioural/psychiatric changes due to female reproductive hormones. Women are generally treated much more seriously by healthcare professionals, tend to have better outcomes, and grow up in an environment that gives them the freedom to express any concerns with their health. Please do not imply its a "women's thing"; as a male with former mental health issues and a current healthcare student mid-way through my degree I can not begin to tell you how much it frustrates me that men do not have the same things as I listed above, not to mention that diseases that predominantly affect women tend to have much more research funding and consequently much better outcomes for their sufferers. I understand that it's difficult for women with their menstruation, hormones, birth control etc., but please don't automatically cry sexism in health care. The reality is just that women have extra layers of complications in their body due to their ability to bear children which is compounded by the inherent complexity of the human body, man or woman.

I'm feeling upset about the start of this episode. 13 Reasons Why is a great show and it does a great job of promoting awareness of mental health issues, but Jessica's spiel at the beginning has rubbed me the wrong way. I strongly disapprove of the way jessica says "boys get to choose their own identity". We are in an age where we are supposed to be enlightened about the realities of the world, yet here they go with Jessica stipulating that boys have it easy and girls have it hard. The world is never black and white, there is no "easy". The idea that boys get to choose their identity is false. The idea we aren't judged on our looks is false. From the age of 11, I have had my looks picked apart by both males and females, and I known more than anecdotally that this is true for many other males. Males are under so much pressure to be the "alpha male", and when you fail in any one aspect, such as being too short, or too fat, or too weak, or having too small a penis, you are picked apart, and you become a nothing, a laughing stock. I have often said that I feel lucky to be gay. In the gay world, I can be who I want to be and I have the genuine ability to express myself. Straight men on the other hand are forced to adhere to codes and conventions, and they are extremely rigid and specific. And harsh. And ultimately unattainable. This is a show that has influence. It is irresponsible of the producers to allow things like this to be said. This spiel of Jessica's ignores the slew of issues that men face, and I am inclined to believe that younger, more impressionable viewers might come under the impression that men "have it easy". We do not have it easy. Why can't the media ever reflect that both men and women have problems.

That #8217;s a good point actually. However, the show shouldn #8217;t be so flippant about having characters say things that minimise the difficulty of being a male. I #8217;m a staunch feminist, so I love that the culture of #8220;slut shaming #8221; and other predominantly-women associated issues are being explored in the show. However, the problem with subtle discussion of male issues is that it relegates the issue itself to the periphery of our awareness; something that #8217;s there, but not something that #8217;s threatening, or important, or anything. Like I #8217;ve said, I #8217;m gay, so in many respects I #8217;m like the bridge between women #8217;s issues and men #8217;s issues. My feminist beliefs are shaped by the knowledge that gay people (particularly men) have been discriminated against because we seem #8220;like women #8221; compared to the straight population. On the other hand, I am still male, and so I have also experienced the crushing pressure that comes alongside that. Having to be tall, athletic, sporty. Having to be financially successful and competitive and strong all the time. The only character in the show that really shows the difficulties of not fitting in to the #8220;perfect boys club #8221; is Tyler, who is repeatedly bullied and ostracised. My overarching issue with this is that male issues are never represented in media and film, despite them being just as present in the western world. It #8217;s not good enough to always be on the periphery anymore.

I think it's also because people are used to the image of women being "penetrated". People generally don't think of men being "penetrated" sexually so it seems more alien and foreign to people. On the other hand, anal rape is more likely to be of serious concern than vaginal rape. Obviously, women can get raped anally as well, but the ass is not very well suited to penetration. It is not as well lubricated as the vagina and not nearly as stretchy. For this reason, anal rape is generally more severe (with regard to physical health consequences), particularly with straight men who have (probably) not been penetrated anally before. As a gay person, it was incredibly painful for me to be penetrated by a partner after stretching for months, so I can't imagine what it would be like to be raped without ever having receiving something in that end. Male rape is very under reported unfortunately. Every now and then, there will be a big blow up in the media, and you #8217;ll realise just how under reported. For example, in Australia, huge amounts of victims spoke out about being sexually abused by catholic priests. 90% of the victims of the priests were boys. It happened at school too; I heard a story about it when I was in year 9, and then after I left someone was gang raped (in a manner similar to Tyler) and suffered serious injuries. I went to a prestigious school, and yet I know of at least 2 stories of serious male rape within five or six years. And those are only ones I heard about, who knows how much worse the problem is? The same deal happened with indigenous Australian boys who went to a special school in the 1950s-1970s, there was serious rape going on there too, and most of the victims were boys.

Well, like I said before, the anus isn #8217;t nearly as suitable for penetration compared to the vagina. This makes it very susceptible to traumatic injury because the tissue in the anus and colon is not as strong as vagina tissue (nor as well lubricated). If perforation occurs in the anus or colon/rectum, aside from the painful aspects of the condition, you are very vulnerable to infection (mainly bacterial), because the anus doesn #8217;t really have any specific defence mechanisms to inhibit bacteria going IN. So obviously, if bacteria migrate to the tear and enter the blood, then the infection can very quickly become systemic and you may go into sepsis and die.

Very well written- although again I think that the level of sexual freedom for gay men is overemphasised. I generally find that the most #8220;out #8221; gay men are the ones who are sexually free, those of us who are from conservative families much less so. You #8217;re also underestimating the impact of social constructs of sexuality in gay culture, particularly the dichotomy of #8220;top #8221; and #8220;bottom #8221;. The idea of gay society being divided on the lines of #8220;tops #8221; and #8220;bottoms #8221; is probably one of the worst things about gay society in my opinion (as a gay person), particularly because being a bottom (or being assumed a bottom by others) often carries with it condescension and being treated degradingly, which is also depressingly anti-feminist. So yes, some men in the gay community might be very sexually free, but a lot of these men are more akin to the #8220;privileged #8221; or top of the hierarchy gays. People like me, who are short and skinny are almost always relegated automatically to the role of bottom, and most men are unwilling to bottom for us because we #8217;re seen as lesser. It #8217;s very painful, let me tell you- I was in an abusive relationship previously where I was always expected to bottom and it was seen as something degrading. Even now, I can #8217;t have sex with my lovely boyfriend because I #8217;ve become so use to the notion that bottoming is degrading that I don #8217;t receive any pleasure from sex at all anymore. While my case is a little more extreme because of the past abuse I suffered, this, I gather, is not actually too uncommon a situation for gay men to experience.

It is discrimination. 25% of HIV cases are transmitted to and between straight people, yet there aren #8217;t any restrictions on them from having sexual activity for over a year. What stinks about this is that two gay people could be in a monogamous relationship long term eachother but that a straight person could theoretically do none of these things and still get a pass. It #8217;s disappointing, because it perpetuates the message that gay people literally have #8220;tainted blood #8221;. Additionally, the #8220;abstain from sex #8221; thing isn #8217;t just from anal sex, it includes oral sex as well, which is statistically very unlikely to transmit HIV to anyone. It #8217;s discrimination presented under a very careful film of being health precautionary.

Thankyou! I am in a committed and monogamous relationship (and am gay), and I hate how we are painted with a tainted brush. What disgusts me is the fact that 20-25% of HIV cases affect straight people; this is a large minority of people for blood banks to ignore. Obviously they ignore because they need blood and straight people are the majority but it is still disgusting; the idea we have tainted blood is archaic and proves that our relationships still aren #8217;t considered equal to straight relationships.

I would hardly call it a vast majority, if you randomly took a group of four people with HIV then three people would probably be gay and one would be straight. That #8217;s not exactly a huge margin. Ultimately, I don #8217;t mind there being stringent guidelines for this sort of thing, but they shouldn #8217;t just apply to gay people on the basis that they are statistically more likely to contract HIV, when a fairly large proportion of cases are contracted by straight people. Not to mention the fact that things like even oral sex between men counts as #8220;sex within the past 12 months #8221;- websites specifically dedicated to HIV say that the chances of transmitting HIV via oral sex are extremely small. Why should this (comparatively much smaller) chance not be taken when straight people have less stringent blood donation guidelines when they make up 1/4 of all HIV cases?

I #8217;m not usually one to cry discrimination because I #8217;m a very scientific person - I #8217;m actually just finishing up a degree in medical science this year. My issue with blood donations isn #8217;t the fact that homosexuals have such stringent guidelines placed on them- this is important to maintain quality of blood. However, around 15-28% of all HIV cases are transmitted between straight people (depends on how the research was undertaken, and when, what statistical analysis was applied etc). While yes, this is a minority in lay people #8217;s terms, this is a large number of people in medical terms. I just feel that straight people should have stricter guidelines. The idea that gay people can #8217;t engage in oral sex then donate blood when a large body of research shows that the chances of contracting HIV from oral sex is minimal when straight people make up to ~25% of all HIV cases is where the discrimination lies. Ultimately the blood donation issue isn #8217;t active discrimination. It #8217;s passive discrimination; the Red Cross have taken appropriate risk for gay people but not necessarily applied it elsewhere.

Given that I #8217;m just finishing up a medical science degree which includes extensive training in epidemiology and biostatistics, I #8217;m going to venture in and say, yes, I do understand math. If you would have read the comment, you would #8217;ve noted that I #8217;m fine with their being stringent guidelines for gay people because yes, the do make up the majority of people affected by HIV. However, the fact that a greater proportion of gays compared to straight people are affected by HIV is not important compared to the actual number of people afflicted (the incidence OR the prevalence depending on what exactly you #8217;re studying). In infectious diseases, 25% of people with HIV not being screened as thoroughly for the disease as the other 75% is a BIG margin. The Red Cross don #8217;t do this because they hate gay people, they do it because obviously they need at least some levels of blood in the blood bank. Again though, if you #8217;d read my comment you would have noted that my biggest problem with this is that straight people aren #8217;t tested rigorously ENOUGH, and also that a gay person engaging in monogamous oral sex (which has an extremely minimal chance of transmitting HIV) is barred from donating blood when a straight person could be promiscuous, have anal sex but then still donate blood. Ultimately, this is an unfortunate consequence of the HIV/AIDS crisis, and many people are still convinced that all gay people are promiscuous and unsafe in their sexual practices. There are other countries that have lower deferral periods for gay people regards blood donation, Japan for example has a 6 month deferral while the UK has 3 months. We #8217;re not asking to be able to walk in, sit down in a chair and donate blood, but we #8217;re asking to be able to donate blood without having to make unreasonable personal lifestyle choices.

It #8217;s not necessarily that they believe that our blood is tainted, but it #8217;s more the social message it sends. It perpetuates the idea that all gay men are inherently promiscuous and unsafe in their sexual practices; this is a reputation we don #8217;t deserve and is hurtful to many of us who have been in stable and long term committed relationships (I am one of these people). There are many countries with a smaller deferral period and there are countries that don #8217;t discriminate between your sex life regardless of whether you #8217;ve had sex with a man or a woman, they just look at whether you #8217;ve been safe and that #8217;s the main thing. I #8217;m not wanting the ability to walk in to a clinic, sign a paper and give blood on the spot, but what I am looking for is the ability to give blood without making unreasonable expectations on me (and my partner). 3 months deferral (like in the UK) I #8217;d be happy to do, even. If they aren #8217;t going to make testing of straight people more stringent, then the only way to please us gay people is to slightly relax the (to be fair, very strict) rules on blood donation. On the other hand, I #8217;m not a healthcare policy maker, nor do I intend to be, so I leave the exact ifs and buts to people who are more legally minded than I. I just want to treat people in peace. :P
No, I don #8217;t think they are opposed to gay men; it #8217;s the social message that is sent by having particularly restrictive guidelines for gay men ONLY that is the problem.

Yes, which was a shame, and a missed opportunity. Unfortunately Australia is a powerhouse for medical research but tends to take a while to actually be progressive in their clinical practice. One of my favourite examples is that in many countries pharmacists prescribe or change dosing of medicines independently of doctors and this has been repeatedly shown to reduce adverse effects associated with drugs, yet we aren #8217;t even close to getting that sort of legislation approved here.

I understand that, but surely you see that that #8217;s the problem? All gay people are grouped into that- why do we deserve to be put on the blood donation back burner with those who are literal prostitutes if we are in monogamous relationships of safe sexual practice? Why can a straight person be relatively promiscuous yet gay people are unable to donate regardless? I don #8217;t mind restrictive legislation but it needs to be leveled out to reflect that a straight person having sex with many people is more likely to have HIV than a gay person who is in a long term monogamous relationship. THATS what really stinks.

I don #8217;t really have distaste towards sex workers or those who have sex with lots of people, but they are more likely to have HIV than two HIV negative monogamous gay partners. This is supported by the epidemiology too - but a lot of the good advice by doctors doesn #8217;t always automatically get taken on board (that #8217;s why it #8217;s advice), and the Red Cross #8217; own personal intentions to change their rules don #8217;t necessarily always line up with what happens in reality (eg having the deferral period to be relaxed slightly rejected).

To be fair though, coming from an Australian outsider point of view, being judged by extracurriculars does seem like a very flawed system. Some people need to devote all their time to study to be kickass at it, and others might not be able to participate in very many extracurriculars because they have a poor family and need to work. The whole point of extracurriculars is that they are extra to the curriculum, and I hardly like the idea of people doing all these extracurriculars just because they need it to go to a competitive college. On a side note, I do think kids need an opportunity to be kids. I went to a school that forced us into a lot of extracurricular stuff and, yes, even thought it does help make you well rounded, I regret doing them now. Why? Because I never ever had a seconds peace. I don #8217;t have holidays because I live on a farm, and then I never had any R and R while I was at school either - it was always go go go. I #8217;d go to choir, or community service, or hockey, or swing band, or SOMETHING and all my friends would be going out and socialising together while I was toiling away in some lame extracurricular that I rarely enjoyed. I did extracurriculars because I #8217;ve lived to a expectation of perfection most of my life, and because people told me it would look good on my resume. It doesn #8217;t. If I had my time again, I would #8217;ve done less extracurriculars and tried to actually experience and enjoy being a teen, rather than being Uber competitive 24/7.

In some sense that #8217;s true, but keep in mind that masculinity in animals generally refers to a discrete set of behaviours (e.g protecting the young, attracting the female). In humans, masculinity is an (increasingly difficult to navigate) spectrum and is not discrete - many of our physical objects are #8220;codes #8221; of symbolic meaning. A male animal would not feel opposed to wearing a dress because wearing a dress is not inherently anything. But in human culture, we have coded wearing a dress as something feminine, so therefore men will generally avoid wearing dresses. A big part of this is a problem because it creates a very large social pressure for men to fit into a tight box of behaviours and attitudes lest they be labelled feminine. Human life is far too complicated for us to still be organising people into narrow categories.

WRITING.TITLE: On Lachlan Watson (Suzie)
WRITING.TEXT: I'm a wee bit confused. I'm gay but I'm not really overtly familiar with non-binary people, though my understanding is that in his case it refers to someone who is essentially gender non-conformist and doesn't neatly fit into male or female gender wise. However, I am a little confused by his character in the show. For one thing, (I'm assuming he was born a male), his voice will eventually break and he will develop a skeletal structure that resembles that of a male. Currently he can pass as a woman quite easily but as he is 17 I doubt that that will last. But his character on the show is obviously a woman; so how does that even work? Are they going to have to kill him off as a character once he develops a conspicuously male physique? They can't have "actually, Suzie is male!" as a plot device because it wouldn't make sense in regards to anything in the entire show. OR am I just completely on the wrong track, and Lachlan was assigned a female at birth but identifies as a male? Or is Lachlan in actuality intersex? I'm just confused and wondering how this will tie in with Suzie as a character, because it would obviously be a very weird plot device for Suzie to turn out to be male in the next season. I have no problem with how Lachlan identifies obviously, I'm just seeking a little clarification on how he identifies and how that relates to the biological aspect of his identity.

Thank you for the explanation! I also did a little bit of digging and found out that the real life Lachlan is biologically a woman but has had top surgery to reduce the emergence of breasts. He identifies closer to a masculine identity and thought he was a trans man growing up but as he got older he discovered the non-binary paradigm fit him much better. I #8217;m really glad that he (and your friend) are being true to themselves in a world that often demonises people for being just that.

Maybe; apparently before Lachlan was cast the character of Susie was intended to come out as trans. I #8217;m not sure if that will happen any more though as Lachlan seems to think he #8217;s changed the producers idea for the character. I also did some research and found out that he is biologically speaking a woman, but has had too surgery to reduce the emergence of breasts, so growing an Adam #8217;s apple and developing a male physique for the character shouldn #8217;t be a problem. :) EDIT: top surgery
They said down the bottom they asked Bosnians Muslim instead.

I actually hope Suzie doesn #8217;t come out as trans. After all, the producers have someone who is legitimately non-binary in their cast who I think is attracting them lots of positive attention. I actually sort of like the idea that Suzie #8217;s gender and/or sexual identity is never explored: it would provide a refreshing perspective for an openly LGBT or non-binary character to not have an overarching plot line that focuses on that aspect of their identity.

On another note, being gay doesn #8217;t actually have really anything to do with testosterone. Testosterone as a circulating hormone is pretty important to a mans health - gay men aren #8217;t just these walking hormone deficient people, otherwise they #8217;d all be sick. Testosterone isn #8217;t really a behavioural hormone as much as it is a regulator of sex drive, it #8217;s main impact on behaviour is aggressiveness. To be fair, this person does make some good points. It seems like Americans really like putting people #8217;s ethnicities into a colour box. I don #8217;t agree that coming from Europe automatically makes you white, because really, what the fuck even is white anyway? People often associate whiteness with fair skin, but also wealthy, coloniser societies and Christianity. My family are Bosnian. Bosnia is Muslim, poor and my skin is brown. I don #8217;t feel white, yet Bosnia is in Europe. Similarly, I #8217;m friends with many Iranian people who are white-skinned, yet they don #8217;t feel any less brown. But this isn #8217;t something we usually have to consider in our home countries in the same perspectives as America views us. We know that skin colour is diverse and that cultures are also diverse, so really, what #8217;s the point of designating people as white, brown, black and yellow? Who gets to be the gatekeeper for these things? Something I #8217;ve found very hard to cope with in life is dealing with people arguing with me about my right to call myself white or brown, as though my designation in society is entirely up to everyone else (which is obviously made 100% more confusing by the fact that everyone says something different lel) and that it #8217;s actually important in the first place. I refuse to answer colour questions when people ask me these days because I #8217;m tired of acting like I belong to some mythical racial meta group when I could really just tell people exactly where I #8217;m from in the first place.

But that doesn #8217;t explain how people sort certain nations into those groups in the first place. Going back to my previous example, If I were to rob someone, I would probably be described as a brown man of short stature and thin build. But then, in another situation, if I were to meet someone, tell them I #8217;m Bosnian, and refer to myself as a brown man, they would act like I #8217;ve just said something crazy. Sure, describing people by their skin colour could help police in a crime scene, but how does society grouping people #8217;s colour based on their country or continent of origin (e.g Europe, Asia) help anyone when every population is diverse in appearance anyway? Either way, you notice that #8217;s not something that #8217;s done in many other parts of the world. Yes if you are robbed you would describe the appearance of the person, but in every day life you wouldn #8217;t have people debating which category you belong to and being like #8220;well hmmm, your skin is brown and you #8217;re from a Muslim country, but also the country is in Europe so hmmm I #8217;m not too sure where to place you #8221; and so on. Like, it #8217;s just so stupid! Something I #8217;ve noticed is that when America collects statistics about its cities and towns, they tend to have statistics like #8220;X town is 75% White, 7% Asian, 9% Black and 9% Hispanic #8221;. Honestly, I think that #8217;s barbaric. In Australia for example, when statistics about the various ethnic groups are collected, the government bases their statistics on country of birth, how you see yourself and what languages are spoken at home. So a given suburb might have #8220;10% people born in the Phillipines #8221; or #8220;29% of the population speak a language other than English at home #8221;. I much much prefer that than belonging to some weird skin colour but also pseudo-ethnoreligiogeographical category that #8217;s not only arbitrary but doesn #8217;t actually seem to be well defined itself.

Thats so ridiculous. In Europe, people don #8217;t define the natives of a nation by their skin colour, they just see them as a European person with brown or white or black skin. It #8217;s not actually like you #8217;re a different race. European American is totally valid because it is far more accurate than #8220;white American #8221;.

gt;Why refer to that at all? I think it's pretty obvious that that was a hypothetical statement, hence why I said "if I were to". When talking to people, ethnicity, race and nationality do have a tendency to come up a lot, especially if you are a person of ambiguous racial appearance. gt;You seem to imply people do this in anything other than specific settings Well I can't account for your experience, but I know that for me people have constantly questioned it. I also know that that is the experience for many other people of ambiguous racial appearance. gt;How are statistics barbaric? I never once said statistics were barbaric. I love statistics. I was criticising how Americans collect and utilise their statistics, which is more an issue with data collection and sample design than the actual concept of utilising statistics to understand people better. gt; a sociopath that's a bit to obsessed with skin colour You're literally pulling random words out of your hat now. Sociopathy is defined as a "mental condition in which a person consistently shows no regard for right and wrong and ignores the feelings and rights of others". Your argument that I'm being too emotional about this issue would therefore indicate that I'm the exact opposite of a sociopath. I don't appreciate you using such strong and unkind words for a simple discussion, especially when my supposed "obsession" with skin colour is more to do with the fact that, for my whole life, people have been obsessed with my skin colour and what it represents me as. That's not something I enjoy (clearly, otherwise why would I be writing this) and for that reason I am sharing my experience of race that I know many other people have also experienced. You also act as though I'm against all designations of colour. Advertising to black people because they have physiologically different types of hair expression isn't racist in any form, nor is advertising tanning cream to people of white skin colour. But that's part of my point precisely: you don't see tanning creams being advertised to *Europeans*, you see them being advertised to people of *fair skin*. After all, not all Europeans have fair skin, and many other people of other continents also have fair skin. So that brings me back to my original point of how in hells name do we think its ok to define an entire race by whether they're from Africa, Europe or Asia or America? The diversity in the human race is large between different countries but also within populations. I'm brown coloured and most of my family is brown coloured, but I also have blood relatives who are blonde and blue-eyed, yet they are still pure Bosnian. In the categories of race constructed by society, does that make them any less brown or more white than I am? After all, they still experience the exact same culture as I do. Yet in Europe, we don't assess things that way. That woman is a Bosnian who is blonde haired and blue eyed. That man is a Bosnian who is brown skinned and dark haired. There's no question of *wow!!!1 Are they brown or white aha I wonder how they identify themselves lol I guess they must be white as they're Europeans but also that dude is pretty dark lol!* We just *are as we are*. The use of categories like white and brown is totally arbitrary to anything because most ethnicities exhibit a diversity of skin colour within their own populations and it implies that cultures, populations, nationalities and ethnicities are far more homogenous than they actually are. gt;It's more pc, but it's not a more functional model Which is literally an assumption you've just made off of nothing. You act like your system is far above the European and Australian system, yet you fail to look at the fact that it's a system that works well for nearly 800 million people. Besides, you talk about people being a melting pot, which is exactly why using designations such as "brown", "white" or "black" **is** barbaric. After all, if people are coming from such a diverse set of cultures, what becomes the dividing line between white, brown and black? Who gets to decide who's who? Are two brothers of African and European descent automatically white because they have European blood? Are they automatically black because they have African blood? Is one **more** black or white than the other because they have a different coloured skin tone? It becomes very murky waters when you start applying these strange "rules" to what a race is. gt;What kind of sick person are you? I'm just as sick as every other person. I'm equally as sick as every fair-skinned person who told me I wasn't allowed to identify as white because I have brown skin. I'm equally as sick as every brown-skinned person who told me I'm not allowed to identify as brown because I'm from Europe. I'm equally sick as the many people who have met me and said "are you brown or white?". I'm equally as sick as the people who seek to debate with me about who I am, and what category I truly belong to. EDIT: And to add to my previous comment: all you #8217;ve done is just confirm what I #8217;m saying. You say that many Americans are highly mixed and therefore it would be too difficult or impossible to identify as #8220;Bosnian French Italian Irish Arab American #8221;. And that is exactly why the categories of white, brown and black are ridiculous. If someone of that ancestry has brown skin, then they should be allowed to refer themselves as a brown person, where #8220;brown #8221; refers *entirely* to the colour of the skin. Not have some stupid checklist where it #8217;s like #8220;oh well yes your *skin* is brown but you #8217;re not Muslim and you have some European heritage so sorry no you #8217;re not allowed to claim this title #8221;. Skin colour is skin colour, and if we #8217;re still going to use terms such as white, brown, black and yellow, they should actually refer to skin colour, not some weird notion of culture, religion and place of origin like it is in today #8217;s society.

Yes, I am aware that people are able to respond how they want. I am sharing my experience of how these labels have been damaging to me and also to many people close to me. You keep saying that no one is trying to choose how I identify, which shows you #8217;re not even bothering to read what I write because that is exactly what I have experienced my entire life. Maybe not on this particular reddit post, but in real life in great quantity? Yes. gt; not try to blame a whole fucking country I haven #8217;t blamed America at all. I have criticised one particular of aspect of something that is an American phenomenon. That says nothing about my belief in the progressiveness of Americans. gt; claim that Americans are the #8220;real #8221; barbarians Again, something I have not once claimed. There #8217;s a theory called the #8220;Gay Uncle Theory #8221; when talking with respect to homosexuals in an evolutionary biology context. As you said, homosexuals wouldn #8217;t normally have children, but the fact that people continue to be homosexual at a consistent rate counters the established concept of natural selection, which would predict that the 0 reproductive success of gay people would result in the trait of homosexuality to be expressed progressively less until its bred out of the population. However, that hasn #8217;t occurred, so it #8217;s theorised that the #8220;gay uncle #8221; may therefore assist other people #8217;s children in survival and development by providing them with extra resources, therefore effectively allowing the gay genetics to carry on.

The "expensive university" thing is more of an American thing than elsewhere, me thinks. In Australia we have the "sandstone universities" which are sort of like the old universities which are stereotyped to be attended by all the private school white people. The difference is that in America to go to an Ivy League or another high up university you often need to not only be very smart but you also need to have significant funds to put you through. That's not the case in many countries like Australia; I can go to almost any university in Australia and it will cost me the same amount of money in tuition (i.e nothing upfront, and the amount you pay for your study only increases with inflation and doesn't accrue interest). I think that's a big problem with these institutions in America - they actively segregate people based on their socioeconomic status, and that perpetuates the socioeconomic structures you have in society and allows it to thrive (for the people at the top). #8203;

Yes, there are obviously differences in skin colour, but the US creates rules whereby you can only identify as a #8220;skin colour #8221; if you come from a certain country, regardless of whether that is your actual skin colour or not. Like, skin colour VARIES greatly WITHIN populations. It #8217;s not like every black person is the exact same shade of colour. Not only that, but by creating a #8220;white #8221; race, #8220;black #8221; race etc you imply that there is actually a connection between the constituent ethnicities of that race. Like, what? Someone living in Lebanon or Turkey is going to have a very different life from someone growing up as ethnically British in the UK. It #8217;s stupid to group people into these incredibly ill-defined and overtly general categories when they really on describe people at the most base level and even then, stereotype them on the basis of what most people believe that nation to be. (Sorry if that was incoherent, but it #8217;s an issue that I find very frustrating!)

I would hardly call it uncommon, 3-10% of the population are LGBT (possibly more given that each new generation people are more comfortable coming out). That #8217;s a similar prevalence to the number of people who have diabetes in the adult population, and you would never call diabetes uncommon. Either way, the issue with heteronormativity is its oppositional dichotomy; the notion that heterosexual identification or behaviour is normal while homosexual behaviour is abnormal. Homosexuality is a normal variant of human sexuality, not an abnormal variant of heterosexuality, which is a better distinction. Especially as no epidemiologist would consider a trait that is prevalent in 3-10% of the population as #8220;abnormal #8221;- that #8217;s more common than having green eyes which, to illustrate my point, is considered a normal variant of human eye colour.

I prefer the word variant because the definition of abnormal is literally #8220;deviating from what is normal or usual; typically in a way that is undesirable or worrying #8221;. Using the word abnormal too frequently to describe homosexual populations is dangerous for us because it can easily tip the delicate scales to convince people that homosexuality too is #8220;undesirable or worrying #8221; Also, the mean wouldn #8217;t be exclusively heterosexual, if you #8217;re assuming the Kinsey scale of sexuality which assumes sexuality represents a spectrum. Even so, we really don #8217;t know exactly how true that statement is anyway. Let #8217;s please never forget that not only was pederasty between men and boys common in Ancient Greek society but that it was also common and encouraged in many Muslim societies for a very long time (up till the late Middle Ages). This was a widespread practice and indicates how societal or cultural beliefs may play a role in the actual expression of sexuality. What we do know is that it certainly isn #8217;t uncommon and probably still not as uncommon as we think it is.

Look, I 100% understand your point, but please don #8217;t talk as though I #8217;m too immature to understand these concepts. I was emotionally and sexually abused as a child. That takes a huge toll on someone #8217;s body image as well as their mental health in general. Especially in my case, where I was forced to be quiet about it due to the shame it would #8217;ve brought my family, and the victim blaming I would #8217;ve suffered as a result. When that has happened to you, you do tend to become both uncomfortable around others but also afraid of others. I was raised powerless and on many days I do still feel powerless. My whole life was built around protecting myself and trying to maintain an outer appearance of happiness and calmness. Similarly, I was also forced to hide I was gay, and the negative comments I received that linked the negative aspects of my appearance to something I didn #8217;t like about myself at the time (and was forced to hide) caused me to live in a constant fear of paranoia and being outed to my family. When you #8217;ve been forced to hide everything about yourself, including things such as sexual abuse because you know the outcome would be worse if you did say something, you do tend to feel like everyone is #8220;out to get you #8221;. It becomes a protective mechanism because you live your life in a constant state of fear that someone may just come along and either push you to the edge or out you in some way to your family, and that would #8217;ve been death for me. I understand I may sound juvenile but please don #8217;t put me in that box. I have been through a lot in my life and have come a long way. I know I still have a long way to go, but just like everyone I have my good days and my bad days. Please don #8217;t judge me on my bad ones. I can #8217;t just #8220;grow out #8221; of my sexual abuse, and my bad days stem from that, not from my personality or my immaturity. EDIT: and in response to the knowledge that #8220;people don #8217;t care that much #8221;, yes, I do understand that, but you also have to understand that from the background I have come from, my brain finds that hard to believe. I would #8217;ve been shamed permanently and blamed for the rest of my life if I had revealed that I had been sexually abused. Same deal for if I had revealed that I was gay. It #8217;s hard for me to believe #8220;people don #8217;t care that much about you #8221; when I have been forced into silence my whole life over the notion that if I ever reveal my truth to anybody, EVERYBODY would care, and everybody would hate me for it.

Not to discredit that violence and sexual assault is a big problem for women, but it #8217;s actually a big problem for men too. The issue is we bury the truth about what happens to men so men don #8217;t go around feeling they need to be careful with themselves. Men feel safe because they #8217;re told they should be, and given the statistics, that #8217;s actually not a good thing. Men make up the majority of victims of violence in Australia, while women make up the majority of sexual assault victims. Men are much more likely to be attacked by strangers while women are usually victimised by people known to them, unfortunately. As a man who has been sexually abused and has narrowly escaped two sexual assaults, I can definitely say that once it #8217;s happened to you, your eyes are opened wide as to the truth that being a man doesn #8217;t make you much safer, and the statistics say the same. I try to tell people this all the time, because if more people understood that men are the main victims of (non-sexual) violence and make up a sizeable portion of sexual violence too (around 25%), then hopefully mental health outcomes could be better for us. I know of course you don #8217;t mean any harm by saying women have to be constantly vigilant (because they do) but i just like to point out that violence against men is actually a very serious, hidden epidemic not many people know about. Lots of men DO know what it #8217;s like to have to look over their shoulder constantly, to never feel safe walking alone in a parking lot and I am one of them. Unfortunately most of us are conditioned to not say anything about our experiences because society just doesn #8217;t have a space for it. I don #8217;t listen to it because fuck that, I #8217;m going to be honest with people about my experience and also the real statistics out there. I hope that if we can raise awareness both about violence against women and men, we can actually put a dent in these crimes and hopefully lead to better societal awareness about the importance of safety first, regardless of gender or sex.

Let #8217;s not also forget that fact that women also suffered severely in war through rape. Sexual violence is HUGE in wars especially in civil/ethnic based war. It #8217;s awful that men have been conscripted and forced to fight in wars since time immemorial, but it doesn #8217;t negate the fact that women #8217;s bodies are also completely devalued during times of war. War is horrible for everyone. I think the saddest part is that even though the men do suffer horribly from the fighting, at least they are venerated when (if) they come home. War rape is something that women have to deal with that there is very little recognition of (at best) or is considered specifically shameful to a family and deliberately hidden (at worst). Most women in non-western countries are never allowed to speak about those events, let alone heal from them.

I have a complicated relationship with my Mum. My dad is almost certainly a narcissist and is really not a great person. My mum is much more black and white. I know she cares about me and loves me, and she shows it in many ways. But on the other hand she has been complicit in my abuse for years and has also contributed in many ways to it over the years (including in her homophobia). At the same time, she has improved over the years as she has gotten wiser and learnt to listen to her children #8217;s emotions. On the other hand, she still won #8217;t stand up to my dad for me, but why would I expect her to? She can #8217;t stand up for herself. She was raised in a very conservative family of Yugoslavs and she has been squashed her entire life for being a woman. She has literally been raised to put up with peoples abuse. When my mum wanted to go and get a tertiary education for herself and got into uni, my baba was so angry with her that she started a bonfire and burned every single one of my mothers possessions she #8217;d ever had. Then my poor Mum ended up marrying into a new Yugoslav family that was even worse than her old one, and she suffered so much abuse that my dad didn #8217;t even bother trying to protect her from, half the time blaming it on her. In short, my Mum has been through a lot, and I don #8217;t want to hurt her. I want to cut dad completely out of my life, but I know that he will only be worse to her. I feel like it might be worth just keeping my distance from him, but not necessarily completely removing him from my life, just so my mum can get some peace as she retires. She has been treated awfully and been let down by every single person in her life. I want her to be able to live better.

Luckily enough I #8217;m fortunate to live in Australia, my family #8217;s ethnic background still kind of pervades everything especially as we live in an area full of people of the same background as us, but I keep myself sane by the fact I get to meet normal people who aren #8217;t fucking crazy in the real world. I agree it is very sad to see the abuse cycle play out in front of you. Still, I haven #8217;t endured even a fraction of what my Mum has, and thankfully I have more agency to have upward social mobility, so it #8217;s not likely that I #8217;ll ever endure what she did. It #8217;s definitely made me a pretty big feminist in the process!

To be fair though, they don't suffer structural racism *currently.* However many older Italian-Americans will tell you a different story from when they first arrived in the US. Most immigrants are treated like shit when they move to a Western country until they have been in the country for a significant period of time and assimilated into the social order of things. Italians had an easier time of assimilation because of their religion but for a long time they were basically considered "semi-coloured". My family are from Yugoslavia (which is honestly much worse than Italy but still) and when they first came to the country the people around them thought of them as "worse than the Aboriginals" (yes that is a direct quote). #8203; I don't blame Joanne for not wanting that solo to be shown on national TV. Just because GiaNina doesn't necessarily experience that structural racism *now* it is still making a mockery of her famiy who did have to experience that to get to where they are now.

I think it's pretty offensive how people just say "you're white so what's the problem" to Italians. They were not perceived as "proper" white when they first arrived in the US, often being labelled "dirty whites", "semi-coloured", "browns" etc. It's just diminishing their experience by being like "omg but you're white!" when for a long time they certainly weren't part of the white club. Especially because lots of Italians have naturally dark skin.

I agree with you Giant\_Anteaters! I am also a boy (although gay admittedly) and the amount of gendering we see in activities is ridiculous. People often say "oh but I wouldn't say ballet is feminine, look how macho male ballet dancers look!", without realising that they have just implied that the reason boys should want to do ballet is because it's **very much masculine and not feminine.** Why should something be lesser because it's feminine? Boys should be encouraged to join any pursuit or field of interest without having to find ways to "prove" its masculinity. You should be able to do whatever you want (provided it doesn't hurt anybody) and not have to explain yourself constantly if it provides you with fulfilment :) #8203; Of course, ballet does take a lot of strength and ballet dancers really are athletes, so there theoretically should be that aspect that would be appealing to "traditional" boys, and you would hope that would make it more marketable to the traditional male audience. Still, it seems like no one is in a hurry to tell boys they can dance, even in 2019 in progressive countries. My cousins (all of whom have young children), some of whom were professional dancers (all female + in ballet) have already gone down the whole route of "our boys are doing football, our girls are doing ballet". Like? How limiting. What happens if your boy wants to do ballet or your girl wants to do football?

Thank god someone said it! Boys DO need feminism too. How can we ever convince men to respect women as equals when we still don't allow men to ever act feminine, or take part in feminine activities? The message is "women can act (similar to) men, and that's ok, because then you're acting "up"" but "boys can't act like women because that's acting "down" a class". It makes me angry when women are homophobic to me or have said "all gays are like women, like, act like a man" and i'm like: "do you even see your own internalised sexism right now!?"

You can make out like you were just framing your interest in someone else #8217;s opinions, but the way you did it was extremely passive aggressive. Also, if someone doesn #8217;t want to discuss their exact opinion on something personal to them with you, leave it. Don #8217;t give them the #8220;I think I will actually #8221;. Nobody owes it to you to share their inner nuances. Also, @OP. I hear you. I am not Black/African American but I am part of the Balkan diaspora. My relationship with my ethnicity was also complicated growing up for a number of reasons. For starters, I was born here, but in many ways I was raised in my culture, with our values, and our beliefs. To make matters more complicated, I have always been treated as #8220;different #8221; by the Anglo-Celtic majority here in Australia, and so being able to perceive myself as wholly Australian with my family from the balkans has been difficult. I imagine it must be even harder for you as my family have only been in this country ~50 years while yours have probably been there for hundreds! I #8217;m going to say right away there is no easy answer. However, you don #8217;t have to go with the grain of any culture. If you don #8217;t like certain aspects of African American culture, you dont have to embody them and you don #8217;t have to like them. You can be an African American with your own interpretation of your culture and history. There is something like 40 million African Americans; there are bound to be likeminded ones somewhere who feel the same way as you. Finding them won #8217;t be easy, but I can promise they #8217;re out there. Even so, individuality should trump your feelings of group identity. While I am ethnically 100% Balkan, I disagree with many aspects of culture, history etc that very much goes against the grain of typical Balkan people. And that #8217;s ok! Honestly, the movie is pretty disgusting and laughably ironic in its premise. The movie uses a tall girl to be the focus on the wider theme that it's ok to be different and not everyone needs to fit in the same box. Then the movie proceeds to: #8203; \- gt; Make sure that the tall girl can't date the short (seemingly Asian) man who is very attracted to her. Of course, she has to date a very tall (extremely White) man, because that's all she can have because \*woe is me\* "i'm tall". As a message, that just increases the pressure for taller young girls to feel like they can only date men taller than them (potentially reducing the likelihood they ever find their perfect partner!), tells tall girls they have to fit into what society thinks of them, and then also willingly perpetuates the stereotype that short men are lesser. This is further expanded on by the "nerdy" personality of the short dude, in comparison to the "hunky" and romantic personality of the tall man. This is a story masquerading to be about body acceptance that is really about body shaming. The overall message of the story? Be slightly different, but in a way that is perceived by society to be dominant, and then be born with the other advantages of having a supportive family, being white and being affluent, and then you will find your prince who also has to have every single one of those traits too. And you will be fine, no worries! #8203; Give me a bucket, this whole movie is a joke. "Body positivity" my ass.

My take on the movie: #8203; \- gt; Instead of teaching viewers that someone's personality and who they are is more important than their height and appearance, viewers are bombarded constantly with the physical aspects of each person and how Jodi is tall. Predictably, the boyfriend is of course not only tall (and smart and funny and romantic!) but also as white as humans can physically be. It's always great to tie in a healthy dose of racism into a movie about body positivity, eh? \- gt; Jodi is privileged as fuck and (acknowledging the movie is supposed to be about her) there is still a ridiculous lack of nuance in the issues that people face outside of being tall. Plus, they don't even approach her height in a way that encourages you to be sympathetic, mainly because they make her seem laughable and like a troll standing next to some gremlins for pretty much the entire movie.

Well, I live in australia and things are a lot more flexible here with regards to race. I know that in America census data specifically records data based on races, so I suppose definitions of race there do have to be very specific. We don #8217;t have that kind of definition in Australia so your race is largely up to how you see yourself and just your outward appearance. I am usually grouped into brown along with most middle easterners and dark Europeans and south Asians, but it #8217;s just a general grouping, not like an actual category. Here, because I don #8217;t look #8220;white #8221; (I.e light skin, western euro features) then I #8217;m not white. EDIT: to add, another common designation for me is #8220;wog #8221;. I #8217;m not sure what the equivalent would be in the US but wogs are considered to be people from Southern Europe, Turkey, Lebanon, Cyprus, and Syria. Wog is again a sort of general ethnic identifier - it carries its own stereotypes of what you are, what you look like, how you speak etc but it #8217;s really an informal category

Well, I think that was inevitable. Chloe has millions of followers on social media and can make thousands of dollars just for posting on instagram. I think Chloe is down to earth, but only relative to other celebrities/influencers. The reality is she lives and has lived a different (and very privileged) from what most people will ever be able to live, so it #8217;s not surprising she would be a little bit removed from reality. I #8217;m not going to lie that the postmates thing gave me a small heart attack though - I chronically meal prep and shop in bulk to save money, because it #8217;s so hard to get ahead in life and I #8217;d really like to save as much as possible as quickly as possible. I think she should be more careful because money can be VERY fleeting and if she plays her cards right, she could easily be set for life with the money she has already earnt and the money she will continue to earn from being an influencer.

To some degree, yes, but that speaks more about her parents than it does her. Just having two college educated parents is indicative of privilege. The very fact Chloe was able to take intensive dance classes and that Christi was even able to go on the show with Chloe (keep in mind they made $600 over the course of season 1) is indicative of a level of privilege that many if not most would not be able to afford. Being on a single parent income for several months would be enough to cripple many families. I #8217;m not saying that Chloe hasn #8217;t worked hard, but it #8217;s just a reality that the life she lives is out of reach for the majority of people. Strictly speaking, it was the growth of a huge fan base that has made her most of her money (i.e through influencing on social media) rather than through Dance Moms. Being able to make money through being an influencer is not the sort of thing that the average person can achieve and no matter which you spin it, you can #8217;t disagree that being able to make money literally by clicking #8220;post #8221; on an app is something that only very few, lucky people can have. You can say they earned their money through hard work, but they reason they were able to earn this money in the first place was through a combination of pure luck, socio-economic privilege, and yes, some talent. Denying otherwise is making a mockery of the hard working working/middle class people who will never be able to experience the life Chloe has had simply due to the circumstances they have grown up in.

I don #8217;t think it #8217;s important that neurodiverse people should be prioritised to play neurodiverse roles. I think it #8217;s different if you #8217;re trans or if you are physically disabled (I.e in a wheelchair), because those are cases where what roles you can get are literally limited by your body #8217;s physiology. Obviously, someone in a wheelchair will be limited to what roles they can play if they can #8217;t walk, so I do think it #8217;s fair to expect that disabled roles should be #8220;reserved #8221; for them. It #8217;s very important to have disabled people on screen - many disabled kids grow up believing that they can #8217;t achieve, or that nobody believes in them, so seeing a disabled actor or disabled character in the media is a big confidence boost.

It got to the point that I always had to angle myself away from people so that they wouldn #8217;t see my side profile. I don #8217;t want her to fall into the trap of feeling like she needs plastic surgery, especially because if she #8217;s talking about her objectively pretty features and then still finding fault in them, then it #8217;s likely that she #8217;ll never be satisfied with the results. Hey, I didn #8217;t do my degree in adelaide, but I #8217;ve just completed my degree in medical sciences :) my recommendation is NOT to do medical sciences if you want to do grad entry medicine. Start with nursing/physio/OT/any other undergrad health degree, and then go from there into graduate medicine. It is much safer.

I #8217;m actually very lucky in that I got a position in clinical research in adelaide :) those jobs are fairly uncommon though and there were a lot of applicants for the position (450 I believe). Other health degrees are safer because they provide you with a pathway to a specific job - e.g if you do nursing you become a nurse, and there are thousands of jobs for nurses and heaps of opportunities available. It means that your qualification is *useful*. So if you don #8217;t make it into med, it means that you haven #8217;t spent the last three years doing a qualification that, for most people, doesn #8217;t lead to a job. Also take into account that med is rough - I know you probably know this, but med sci is like medicine lite and even med sci can be *soul crushing*. I started med sci wanting to do medicine and I no longer want to do it (though I have extenuating circumstances that are also playing into that). If you find at the end of your degree you don #8217;t want to do med, it #8217;s better to at least have a health qualification like nursing so you at least have something useful to fall back on. I should probably let you know also that biomed and med sci are usually basically the same thing, although maybe they #8217;re different in SA. Don #8217;t do forensic sciences, it absolutely won #8217;t get you a job as lots of people do it. If you can do it as a second major/minor go ahead and do it though.

That #8217;s not too bad as a last resort :) though keep in mind that if Chem eng isn #8217;t an honours degree, you #8217;ll need the postgrad to get work as an engineer (I know this because my brother is an engineer). Are you completely against doing nursing or physio?

If sciences are your main interest, may I ask why you are keen on medicine specifically? As the other health degrees cover a lot of the same content, as well as prepare you for a life in healthcare (sort of like a test run). If you are very purely science oriented, I would probably recommend you stick with engineering.

Mainland Greeks will usually have some Slavic DNA, so if your grandmother was from the mainland then she #8217;d probably have given you the Eastern European.

Ok, but statistics from western countries, certainly so in my country, show that men are actually more likely to be victims of stranger violence than women. Most violence against women is perpetrated by people known to them, which is of course awful, but the notion that men don #8217;t feel afraid and shouldn #8217;t *need* to is also a problem. A big part of me feels men don #8217;t feel afraid because men aren #8217;t told the truth about how common it is to be the victim of violence and sexual assault. If they knew, they might feel differently. I am a man and have felt scared walking by myself in all sorts of places, and I have also been sexually assaulted by a stranger, so these things do happen. It frustrates me when people say #8220;I had to put myself into a woman #8217;s shoes to understand what it #8217;s like to be afraid in a public place! #8221; Yes, many if not most women feel that way, but keep in mind that men are both encouraged not to feel afraid and also socially stigmatised for ever admitting to feeling afraid, so please don #8217;t imagine this is something that isn #8217;t a problem for men by any stretch.

Literally none of that statement at all needs to be addressed by feminism. I am a feminist. The fact remains that women and men tend to be recipients of violence from different sets of people. I have not denied violence against women, nor have I denied that there are still more cases (in number) of violence against women than there are men AFAIK. What I #8217;m saying is that the skew in proportion in violence against women (as opposed to men) is nowhere near as strong as most people would imagine it. So there are a large number of men who are living in a world where their experiences are constantly being invalidated before they even have a chance to say anything. We need to **stop** saying #8220;oh men don #8217;t feel afraid to walk in public places #8221;, when many do. Many do and many have too much personal reason to understand what it #8217;s like. No one ever talks about how men can have panic attacks just being in public. No one talks about the man who was raped in a bush. No one talks about these things and people act like they don #8217;t happen. So don #8217;t act like I need feminists to #8220;address #8221; this statement like I #8217;ve said something fucking horrible. Accept that we live in a world that can be horrible and not only women are capable of being victimised. Have some empathy and realise #8220;huh, maybe this stuff actually *does* happen and I #8217;ve just been programmed by society to not think so #8221;.

I #8217;m going to do that, because the whole point is that as soon as someone points out that feeling afraid is also something that is experienced by men, it gets shut down because women experience it #8220;more often #8221;. If I ever heard people say #8220;oh yeah there are plenty of men who don #8217;t feel afraid #8221; then I would be fine. And on another note, are not enough men feeling afraid? Do men not feel afraid because they genuinely aren #8217;t in danger, or is it because society tells them they don #8217;t have a reason to be afraid? I know lots of men who say stuff like #8220;oh well I #8217;m a 6 foot, 95kg footballer, I wouldn #8217;t have any problems #8221;, yet that didn #8217;t stop my cousin #8217;s friend (literally a 6 #8217;5 #8221;, 110kg footballer) from getting mobbed and having his jaw broken and abdomen slashed at complete random and out of nowhere one night. My point is that people *in general* need to be more aware of the dangers that are out there. If anything, hearing that men #8220;don #8217;t need to be afraid #8221; or #8220;men don #8217;t have to be afraid #8221;, which I have heard a lot lately in my country, is incredibly invalidating for someone who is a literal victim of sexual assault by a stranger in a public place.
Well I don #8217;t necessarily agree with all of your points, but I do agree with some of them, so I guess we can agree to disagree.

Hello fellow Australian! In a way similar to African Americans, most indigenous Australians have white heritage as well for not so good reasons. However, most indigenous people today will still identify as indigenous regardless of how much they have. Your Mum may be half in the sense that her dad was white and *her* Mum was aboriginal, but she would most likely be less than half aboriginal genetically because her aboriginal lineage was probably mixed with white ancestors when the British colonised Australia. Career question - should I do medical imaging or nursing? Just for some context, I currently work in medical research in Australia: here medical imaging is a 4 year bachelors degree training you in x ray and basic training in other modalities (excluding sonography). Nursing is a 3 years bachelor degree or a 2 years master degree. I #8217;ve been thinking about going into medical imaging for a long time - the physics and technological side really appeal to me, and I love anatomy because I personally find it much more challenging than physiology. However, heaps of people have told me that medical imaging is boring and repetitive, and that all radiographers/medical imaging technologists do is push buttons. While that may or may not be true for x ray, what are the other modalities like? The thing I find challenging though is that I #8217;m also interested in being involved in #8220;hands on #8221;, procedural work. I #8217;ve looked into areas like Cath lab radiography and it seems like this is much more involved - I #8217;ve seen job descriptions that indicate that MITs would assist the cardiologist in using pressure injectors, intravascular ultrasound etc. Can anyone fill me in on what this type of role is like and how involved the imaging technologist would actually be in this process? And in a more general sense, could someone explain to me why modalities outside of x ray are generally considered more challenging and rewarding? Any help would be appreciated :) The reason I also consider nursing is because there is such a diverse set of career options you can have and there #8217;s plenty of hands on stuff.
