Do I get privilege for being male though? Granted, I see myself as a non-binary gay male (if that makes sense), but I #8217;ve never felt that I #8217;ve ever been afforded male privilege. Rather, I #8217;ve felt that being a male who is gender non-conforming has just completely destroyed any respect or credibility I would be afforded normally. I have been discriminated against at my workplace (that is 90% women by the way), for essentially not being male #8220;enough #8221;. I have been denied promotions for not #8220;having enough authority #8221; or the #8220;presence #8221; to delegate tasks, and been told I #8217;m too #8220;friendly and passive #8221;. You can say that this isn #8217;t sheer proof I was discriminated against because of my gender behaviour, but in context it was obvious when I was getting the feedback that I wasn #8217;t #8220;alpha male #8221; enough for the job. Then, we I did finally receive a promotion, I was given the job at a lower pay rate than the cis straight male who was promoted three weeks before me (about 6K less as a matter of fact), despite the fact I have more experience and am equally as proficient in the job. Socially, I have always felt the same. The greatest transgression for a male is to act feminine. The sheer fact I do so (and I #8217;m not even the most feminine gay person out there!) has made me a constant target of ridicule and disrespect. I have to work really hard just to get other women to respect me half the time, let alone other men. Regarding my own safety, this is something I also feel is lacking. The amount of times I #8217;ve been yelled at, heckled, been sexually assaulted, been threatened... I do truly wonder if it will ever end. People act like only women have to walk with their keys out between their fingers, and only women need to worry about their safety in a dark parking lot. But I #8217;ve been worrying about those things since I was a young boy! obviously I #8217;m not saying women aren #8217;t discriminated against because they absolutely are (and I #8217;m a huge feminist myself), but my point is that I think being gay and even remotely stereotypical greatly diminishes any privilege you receive for being male. There #8217;s a reason why straight boys will often use it as the worst insult (especially in schools + police etc). It #8217;s because you surrender a great deal of male privilege once you come out as gay. Life is a trial #129396;.

Being male does not mean I can automatically fight other men off. We are not all created equally. Not one of my abusers was I able to fight off. I think it #8217;s the feeling of constantly fighting. *fighting* to be recognised, *fighting* to not be disrespected, *fighting* to love myself. I have learnt throughout my life that being gay and even remotely femme (I see myself as non-binary), and also #8220;looking gay #8221; is an instant hit to your credibility wherever you go. I am used to being seen as lesser and I #8217;m tired of fighting it. I #8217;m tired of having to explain to people how their actions and words are often casually homophobic. I #8217;m tired of experiencing internalised homophobia from other gay people. I #8217;m tired of trying to find a man to date that #8217;s not problematic and toxic. I #8217;m tired of being in my twenties and not ever being able to find a single man who has life together and is emotionally mature. I #8217;m tired of gay people seemingly never bothering to go on actual dates. I #8217;m tired of never being able to find other like-minded gay people. I feel like I #8217;m a black sheep. Being gay is exhausting. I #8217;d be lying if I didn #8217;t say I wish I wasn #8217;t gay. Because my entire life has been trial after trial after trial, and I #8217;m sick of having people shame me for any gay trait I express. I #8217;m sick of being body shamed by gay people for not being masculine enough, and then being body shamed by straight people for being too feminine. Gay people need to do more to band together instead of being toxic and bringing eachother down all the time.

I honestly think a move would be great. Are your options in your field so limited that NONE of your training would be transferable to another country? I know you say the younger generation are accepting but as fellow ex-Yugoslav gay person I think you would really benefit from being somewhere where the majority are accepting. However, I #8217;m not sure you should move for love specifically. I think you should start building a career and a happier life for yourself first in Macedonia, take some time to figure out what you want and then move elsewhere. I know the idea of moving seems scary, but there are millions of immigrants around the world in the exact same position! Think of how common it is for Balkan people especially to leave their home countries and to emigrate elsewhere. There #8217;s nothing special about them - you #8217;re just as capable as they are and I think a new perspective in a new place would be great for you :)

That #8217;s great you already have those things then. Do you mind if I ask what field you are in? Also when I #8217;m talking about being settled, I #8217;m also talking about working on being happier before you move. I have learnt from experience that expecting #8220;moving to a new place #8221; to solve all my problems didnt do that. It definitely helped, but there are also lots of other things I dragged with me. Some of that is unavoidable, but some it isn #8217;t. Do you have activities that you do that make you feel happy?

Love that! I #8217;m not trying to doubt that your degree isn #8217;t transferable at all, but you must be eligible for credit in some country? I just had a look at pharmacist accreditation in the UK and it certainly seems possible that you could transfer there (not saying it would be logistically easy, just throwing things at the wall). That being said, I also think you should take some time to work on your self and try something new to focus on. I personally love singing and piano and these are things that help distract me when I #8217;m not feeling great. In addition to that, I think you should look into getting some assistance for your mental health. I saw some of your other posts and please, PLEASE, *please* do not kill yourself. You are worth so much more than you know and you deserve to understand that. I would be very sad if you killed yourself and I don #8217;t even know you! I know how much effort it takes to escape the grasps of depression, but please looking into getting help. I know the stigma is really strong against mental health in Macedonia, but if you can #8217;t get help, please at least look into developing strategies that help to make you feel better. I find writing down things that I #8217;m grateful for is a really helpful way for me to feel better when I #8217;m sad :)

WRITING.TITLE: Anyone else starting to feel not good enough?
WRITING.TEXT: I haven #8217;t been on a date in months and haven #8217;t had sex in over a year. Yes, I #8217;m sure I could find something casual, but that #8217;s not what I #8217;m looking for. I #8217;m looking for a relationship. I #8217;m 22 and I feel like I #8217;m doing all the right things. I finished uni last year and got excellent marks, went straight into a full time job interstate and am completely financially independent. I #8217;m very capable of being independent in other facets (eg cooking for myself, fixing things) and very mindful of my physical and mental health. I have a few extracurricular activities that I enjoy and a small group of friends that I associate it with frequently, though I get along with most people fairly easily. So why can #8217;t I find anyone? I #8217;m a little bit picky, but the people I swipe right on on dating apps are hardly the bees knees. Yes I don #8217;t like super skinny guys, but it #8217;s not like I #8217;m only looking for muscular guys. I have consistently reassessed what I like in a man and I don #8217;t think what I ask for is too insane: - not extremely skinny or extremely muscly. I like an average guy or stocky guy - not into blonde at all - must have some sort of trajectory in life - must be an empathetic person and educated on suffering around the world ... and that #8217;s about it. Yet on dating apps, I feel invisible. I rarely get matches. In real life I feel invisible too, it #8217;s like men don #8217;t find me attractive or interesting or worthwhile. I used to be so confident that I was somebody special but I don #8217;t have that anymore. When I was in my previous city, I never felt like it was this hard, now I #8217;ve moved and I feel like no one would even date me. What am I doing wrong? I know people are superficial, so I immediately jump on the #8220;there must be something wrong with the way I look #8221; train. I see myself as moderately attractive, but maybe I #8217;m wrong. Yes, I #8217;m on the skinny side, but I #8217;m fit and lean; yes I #8217;m on the short side, but surely 175cm isn #8217;t considered *that* short? Am I really that repugnant? I just have no concept of why I can #8217;t find anyone to date at all. Am I unloveable? I used to feel like anyone and everyone could love me, but since moving to this new city, I #8217;m starting to feel like the only person who #8217;ll appreciate me for who and what I am is myself. Has anyone else had this experience/these feelings?
Thanks for the sarcasm! It just made my whole day.
